text:
It sounds like you were hacked. Not necessarily by an unhappy employee. This is quite common on WordPress sites.
1. Don’t waste your effort on fixing the links first. If it’s a backdoor SQL injection it will come back. 
2. Restore the site if you can. Then change admin passwords, server, WordPress admin etc. In the days when I did this type of work I’d even go to the extreme measures to change the hosting provider. It’s very difficult to get rid of a hack especially if you’re targeted.
3. Reinforce WordPress (there is a plugin iThemes Security that can help).
Let me know if you need help and I know some experts who can help with this situation.

elements.text: It sounds like you were hacked. Not necessarily by an unhappy employee. This is quite common on WordPress sites.
Don’t waste your effort on fixing the links first. If it’s a backdoor SQL injection it will come back.

Restore the site if you can. Then change admin passwords, server, WordPress admin etc. In the days when I did this type of work I’d even go to the extreme measures to change the hosting provider. It’s very difficult to get rid of a hack especially if you’re targeted.
Reinforce WordPress (there is a plugin iThemes Security that can help).
Let me know if you need help and I know some experts who can help with this situation.

text:
See if your brand is uniquely positioned to knock one of those topics out of the park with a post that will definitely surpass what's currently in the SERPs, and focus on that. If you're in the low KD realm, stick with bottom-of-the-funnel keywords.

If you think there's no possibility of that working, perhaps focus on improving your site's authority (how you do this will depend on how much budget you have) while finding other ways to promote the most useful content for your audience -- do you have any other established channels like email, social, etc.? Could be SEO isn't the best channel yet until you've built up more brand authority/awareness.

elements.text:
See if your brand is uniquely positioned to knock one of those topics out of the park with a post that will definitely surpass what's currently in the SERPs, and focus on that. If you're in the low KD realm, stick with bottom-of-the-funnel keywords.

If you think there's no possibility of that working, perhaps focus on improving your site's authority (how you do this will depend on how much budget you have) while finding other ways to promote the most useful content for your audience -- do you have any other established channels like email, social, etc.? Could be SEO isn't the best channel yet until you've built up more brand authority/awareness.

text: Building up a good foundation of long-tail keywords with low volume/difficulty and <https://nichesiteproject.com/keyword-golden-ratio/|KGR terms>. It will take some time, but once the snowball gets rolling, you’ll start to rank for more and more keywords. Link building is also important for increasing domain authority and getting individual blogs ranking faster (our company focuses heavily on guest blogging).

text:
Hi all, happy Friday!
What data do you use to develop benchmarks for SEO metrics like website traffic, blog traffic etc.? Let's say it's for a website that recently started regularly publishing blogs (whereas it previously rarely published blogs)? Do you put the benchmark as a certain percentage higher than the average?

elements.text:
Hi all, happy Friday!
What data do you use to develop benchmarks for SEO metrics like website traffic, blog traffic etc.? Let's say it's for a website that recently started regularly publishing blogs (whereas it previously rarely published blogs)? Do you put the benchmark as a certain percentage higher than the average?

text:
• Metrics in GSC (visibility)
• Organic Search traffic to the site
• Conversions on site

elements.text: Metrics in GSC (visibility)
Organic Search traffic to the site
Conversions on site

text: I would pull traffic numbers for the blog from Google Search Console (organic traffic and impressions) and Analytics (bounce rate, time on page, etc) and the SEMRush for increase in number of keywords ranked.

elements.text: I would pull traffic numbers for the blog from Google Search Console (organic traffic and impressions) and Analytics (bounce rate, time on page, etc) and the SEMRush for increase in number of keywords ranked.

text: <@U032CDBUQ0N> - good suggestion on num keywords ranked. That would show up sooner and be a solid indicator of positive action

text:
Thanks <@UJE5LARL0> and <@U032CDBUQ0N>! I think I may have worded my question in a confusing way, what I meant was more of "what do you when establishing goals for metrics"? For example, how can I set a benchmark that is realistic but also an improvement?

Thanks <@UUXMCJQ15>! Is that data based on competitors for the client? How do you create that projection?

text: We still go after them. We consistently go up against Healthline and that crowd and manage to compete fairly well without building links. We just focus on topical authority (e.g. focusing on content hubs with great internal linking and UX) instead.
